text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zambia press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- United National Independence Party (UNIP) yesterday expelled three of its vocal members, Lieutenant-General Benjamin Mibenge, member of the central committee, Sam Moyo and Arnold Chooka for allegedly disparaging the integrity of the party.
- Ten more Burundian soldiers have been handed over to police by government authorities in Luapula province, bringing the number of soldiers being held in Mansa to 20.

- UNIP member of the central committee Sam Moyo, former party secretary general, Benjamin Mibenge and former aide to UNIP leader Kenneth Kaunda, Arnold Chooka, have been expelled from the party with immediate effect.
- Expelled UNIP member of the central committee, Sam Moyo, disclosed yesterday that his party had paid witnesses in the petition against the election of President Chiluba.
- Defence counsel of former president Kenneth Kaunda yesterday told Ndola High Court Judge Sylvester Simachela that Kaunda was wrongly petitioned over his nationality under the Bill of Rights.
- Delving into President Frederick Chiluba's parcel of neckties and pocket hankies landed a Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) clerk in "hot soup" recently.

- The life of presidential petition witness Theresa Mulenga Kalo is threatened by security officers, said Sachika Sitwala, of lighthouse chambers, one of the lawyers of the petitioners, in a letter to the Inspector General of Police.
